title: What tube lines are affected by the Extinction Rebellion?
text:
A protestor at Shadwell station (Picture: Vladimir Morozov / Alamy Live News)

The Extinction Rebellion (XR) have engaged in tube disruption this morning, October 17, with a protestor being dragged off the top of a train at Canning Town station by angry commuters.

In a video, two men can be seen standing on the roof of the train, as commuters jeer their actions before a man on the platform jumps up and pulls an activist down onto the platform.

An XR press officer filming the chaos was also attacked when the crowd realised his connection to the protesters, later telling the camera he was ‘beaten by a mob of people’.

This action was part of planned disruption deliberately targeting the London tube.

What tube lines are affected by the Extinction Rebellion today?

XR website says that there have been ‘XR affinity groups’ targeting the DLR at Shadwell this morning in addition to today’s action at Canning Town.

According to the Evening Standard, XR has said that the organisation will not be taking any further action on the London Underground today.

However, a tweet sent this morning from the Extinction Rebellion London Twitter account highlights: ‘Tactical decisions are taken by small groups within the movement, who lead their own actions.

Tactical decisions are taken by small groups within the movement, who lead their own actions. This is empowerment. The climate crisis is a crisis for everyone & everyone must make their own decisions on the actions they will take. XR is guided by principles, not executives. pic.twitter.com/J2jNuLm64N — Extinction Rebellion London (@XRLondon) October 17, 2019

‘This is empowerment.’

This would seem to suggest that there’s always a chance there could be disruption anywhere and at any time.

Protests at Canning Town underground station (Picture: Extinction Rebellion)

On the subject of the action taken today, XR Spokesperson Robin Boardman, 21, said none of the protestors wanted to ‘inconvenience ordinary people’.

He added: ‘That’s why we’re doing this in the morning when it will impact business as usual, and not in the evening, when people want to get home to be with their loved ones.’

Detailing why they chose to target the tube, the XR website reads: ‘As with a labour strike, economic disruption is key in forcing the Government to come to the table and negotiate our demands.

‘XR creates mass disruption to highlight the emergency.’

Canning Town was targeting this morning (Picture: Twitter/gretchen_red)

The website also included an apology which reads: ‘We sincerely apologise to all those who may be affected as a consequence of this disruption.

‘In any other circumstances these groups would never dream of disrupting the Tube but this is an emergency.’

What are the protestors planning at Gatwick?

From 11am today, activists are due to arrive for planned ‘mischief’ at Gatwick Airport.

The demonstration is set to be held at the South Terminal, and, according to the group’s Telegram channel, activists have been urged to ‘come incognito’, while ‘musicians, clowns and singers’ were also welcomed to join in.

Flights are not expected to be disrupted, with a spokesperson for XR telling Metro.co.uk: ‘Its purpose is to be fun and cheeky, not to cause travel chaos.’
description: The Extinction Rebellion have engaged in planned tube disruption this morning, October 17. They're also planning on taking action at Gatwick.
